abstract: Center on Privacy and Technology at Georgtown University calls on Congress and state legislatures to pass laws creating stricter regulations on use of facial recognition software; report raises concerns of potential abuse by law enforcement, finding 16 states allow police to compare faces of suspects to photographs on driver's licenses without warrant; report also notes that because African-Americans come into disproportionate contact with law enforcement, they could be unfairly over-represented in facial recognition databases.

keywords.value: Center on Privacy and Technology at Georgetown Law Center
keywords.name: organizations

lead_paragraph: Software comparing suspects’ faces to ID photos without a warrant threatens privacy and disproportionately affects African-Americans, a report found.

headline.main: Study Urges Tougher Oversight for Police Use of Facial Recognition
headline.print_headline: Study Urges Stricter Rules for Photo ID Technology
